sen.j: 帝釈天（たいしゃくてん）は、仏教の守護神である天部の一つ。
sen.e: Taishakuten is one of the Tembu, Deities of Buddhism who reside in a heavenly realm, one of six realms in which the souls of living beings transmigrate from one to another.
Taishakuten is one of the Tembu, deities of Buddhism who reside in a heavenly realm, this being one of six realms in which the souls of living beings transmigrate from one to another.
Taishakuten is one of the Tenbu, deities of Buddhism who reside in a heavenly realm, this being one of six realms in which the souls of living beings transmigrate from one to another.

sen.j: バラモン教・ヒンドゥー教・ゾロアスター教の武神でヒッタイト条文にもみられるインドラと同一の神。
sen.e: The war god of Brahmin, Hindu and Zoroastrianism and the same god as Indra which is seen in the clauses of Hittite.
sen.cmt: インドラ→英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: It is the war god of Brahmin, Hindu and Zoroastrianism and the same god as Indra that is seen in the clauses of Hittite.
It is the war god of Brahmin, Hindu and Zoroastrianism and the same god as Indra that is seen in the clauses of Hittite.

sen.j: 釈提桓因（しゃくだいかんいん）とも称する。
sen.e: It also names Shaku Daikanin.
It is also called Shaku Daikanin.
It is also called Shaku Daikanin.

sen.j: 釈は字（あざな）、提桓因は天主のこと。
sen.e: Shaku is Azana and Daikanin means most High.
sen.cmt: 字→定訳不明、天主→英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Shaku is Azana, and Daikanin means "most high."
Shaku is Azana, and Daikanin means "most high."

sen.j: 梵天と一対の像として表されることが多い。
sen.e: It is often shown as a pair of statue with Bonten, Brahma, a major Hindu deity thought to be responsible for creating the world.
It is often shown as a pair of statues with Bonten (Brahma), a major Hindu deity thought to be responsible for creating the world.
It is often shown as a pair of statues with Bonten (Brahma), a major Hindu deity thought to be responsible for creating the world.

sen.j: 阿修羅の娘であるシャチー（シャチー）の夫
sen.e: It is a husband of Sachi, a daughter of Ashura.
It is the husband of Sachi, a daughter of Ashura.
It is the husband of Sachi, a daughter of Ashura.

sen.j: 帝釈天の名はインドラの名前のサックロ・デヴァーナーム・インドラ（Sakro Devanam Indrah）のうち、サックロを釈と音訳したものに、デヴァーナームを天と意訳して後部に付け足し、インドラを帝と意訳して冠したもの。
sen.e: The name of Taishakuten (帝釈天) originates from Indra's name, Sakro Devanam Indrah, as follows; Sakuro is transliterated to 釈, Devanam is translated freely to 天 and Indrah is translated freely to 帝 and put on the first.

The name of Taishakuten (帝釈天) originated from Indra's name, Sakro Devanam Indrah, as follows: Sakuro is transliterated to 釈, Devanam is translated freely to 天, and Indrah is translated freely to 帝 and placed first.

The name of Taishakuten (帝釈天) originated from Indra's name, Sakro Devanam Indrah, as follows: Sakuro is transliterated to 釈, Devanam is translated freely to 天, and Indrah is translated freely to 帝 and placed first.

sen.j: 本来のインドラ神は、阿修羅とも戦闘したという武勇の神であったが、仏教に取り入れられ、成道前から釈迦を助け、またその説法を聴聞したことで、梵天と並んで仏教の二大護法善神となった（インドラの項を参照）。
sen.e: Original Indra was a war god who fought with Ashura, but became one of the two good major Deities of Buddhism with Bonten after it was incorporated to Buddhism and considered to have helped Shaka before getting enlightenment and hear its preach (see the article of Indra).

Originally, Indra was a war god that fought with Ashura, but it became one of the two good major deities of Buddhism with Bonten after it was incorporated to Buddhism, and it was considered to have helped Shaka before gaining enlightenment and hearing its preaching (see the article on Indra).

Originally, Indra was a war god that fought with Ashura, but it became one of the two good major deities of Buddhism with Bonten after it was incorporated to Buddhism, and it was considered to have helped Shaka before gaining enlightenment and hearing its preaching (see the article on Indra).

sen.j: 四天王などを配下とし、須弥山の頂上・忉利天の善見城に住むとされる。
sen.e: It is said that it has some followers such as Shitenno, Four Guardian Kings, and lives at Zenken-jo Castle in the top of Mt.Shumisen, the Touriten.
sen.cmt: 四天王→http://www.aisf.or.jp/%7Ejaanus/、須弥山→http://www.aisf.or.jp/%7Ejaanus/、忉利天→http://www.aisf.or.jp/%7Ejaanus/、善見城→kotobank
sen.e: It is said that it has some followers such as the Shitenno (four guardian kings) and lives at Zenken-jo Castle atop Mt. Shumisen (the Touriten).
It is said that it has some followers such as the Shitenno (four guardian kings) and lives at Zenken-jo Castle atop Mt. Shumisen (the Touriten).

sen.j: インドにおける仏伝図様においては、釈迦に従う帝釈天の様子が描かれることがある。
sen.e: There is a Buddhism pictures of India, in which Taishakuten who follows Shaka has been drawn.
There are Buddhist pictures of Indra, in which Taishakuten, who follows Shaka, has been drawn.
There are Buddhist pictures of Indra, in which Taishakuten, who follows Shaka, has been drawn.

sen.j: 涅槃経巻33や大智度論巻56には、帝釈天が人間だった頃の名前は憍尸迦（きょうしか、Kauśika）であると説かれている。
sen.e: In the Vol.33 of Nehan-kyo Sutra (The Sutra of The Great Nirvana) and the vol.56 of Daichidoron, there is a description that Taishakuten named Kyoshika （Kauśika） when he was a human.
In Vol. 33 of Nehan-kyo Sutra (The Sutra of the Great Nirvana) and Vol. 56 of Daichidoron, there is a description that Taishakuten was called Kyoshika （Kauśika）when he was a human.
In Vol. 33 of Nehan-kyo Sutra (The Sutra of the Great Nirvana) and Vol. 56 of Daichidoron, there is a description that Taishakuten was called Kyoshika （Kauśika）when he was a human.

sen.j: かつて昔にマガダ国の中で名を摩伽（まか）、姓を憍尸迦という、福徳と大智慧あるバラモンがいた。
sen.e: In the ancient times, in Mahadh there was a Brahmin whose first name was Maka and family name was Kyoshika with good deeds (福徳) and great wisdom.
sen.cmt: マガダ国→http://www.mncango.org/,福徳→定訳不明、goo辞書
sen.e: In ancient times, in Mahadh there was a Brahmin whose first name was Maka and family name was Kyoshika, and who did good deeds (福徳) and had great wisdom.
In ancient times, in Mahadh there was a Brahmin whose first name was Maka and family name was Kyoshika, and who did good deeds (福徳) and had great wisdom.

sen.j: 彼には知人友人が32人いて共に福徳を修して命終して、須弥山の頂の第2の天上に生まれた。
sen.e: It had 32 acquaintance and friends to learn and do good deeds together, and was reborn in the second world above on the top of Mt.Shumisen after death.
He had 32 acquaintances and friends with whom to learn and do good deeds, and after death he was reborn in the second world above on the top of Mt. Shumisen.
He had 32 acquaintances and friends with whom to learn and do good deeds, and after death he was reborn in the second world above on the top of Mt. Shumisen.

sen.j: 摩伽バラモンは天主となり、32人は輔相大臣となったため、彼を含めた33人を三十三天という。
sen.e: Maka Brahmin became most High and 32 acquaintance and friends became ministers to give advice so that 33 including him are called Thirty-three Ten.
Maka Brahmin became most high, and 32 acquaintances and friends became ministers to give advice so that 33 (including him) are called the 33 Ten.
Maka Brahmin became most high, and 32 acquaintances and friends became ministers to give advice so that 33 (including him) are called the 33 Ten.

sen.j: これゆえに釈迦仏は彼の本名である憍尸迦と呼ぶという。
sen.e: For this reason Shaka Buddha calls him as Kyoshika, his true name.
For this reason Shaka Buddha calls him Kyoshika, his true name.
For this reason Shaka Buddha calls him Kyoshika, his true name.

sen.j: また、このために彼の妻・舎脂を憍尸迦夫人と呼ぶこともある。
sen.e: Moreover, his wife Sachi is called Mrs.Kyoshika in some cases.
Moreover, his wife Sachi is in some cases called Mrs. Kyoshika.
Moreover, his wife Sachi is in some cases called Mrs. Kyoshika.

sen.j: 日本では、頭上に宝髻を結び、中国式の礼服を着た二臂像として表現されることが多い。
sen.e: In Japan it is often expressed as a two upper bodies statue (二臂像) with his hair tied in a treasure bun (宝髻) on the top of the head and putting on Chinese formal clothes.
In Japan it is often expressed as a statue with two upper arms (二臂像), its hair tied in a treasure bun (宝髻) atop the head, and dressed in Chinese formal clothes.
In Japan it is often expressed as a statue with two upper arms (二臂像), its hair tied in a treasure bun (宝髻) atop the head, and dressed in Chinese formal clothes.

sen.j: また、着衣下に甲冑をつけることもあり、手には金剛杵や蓮茎などを執ることがある。
sen.e: In some cases he puts on an armor under clothes and Kongosho or a lotus root in his hand.
In some cases he wears armor under the clothes and has a kongosho or a lotus root in his hand.
In some cases he wears armor under the clothes and has a kongosho or a lotus root in his hand.

sen.j: 密教においては、一面二臂で、冠を戴き、身体には甲冑を着け、手には独鈷杵を執る例が見られる。
sen.e: In Mikkyo, Esoteric Buddhism, there are some examples that he has one face and two upper bodies (一面二臂) with a crown on the head, armor on the body and Tokkosho, a pestle with a single sharp blade at each end, found as an attribute of Buddhist guardian figures, and a symbolic item in Esoteric Buddhism, in his hand.
sen.cmt: 密教→http://www.koyasan.or.jp/english/shingonshu/mikkyo.html,一面二臂→定訳不明、独鈷杵→http://www.aisf.or.jp/%7Ejaanus/
sen.e: In Mikkyo (Esoteric Buddhism) there are some examples in which he has one face and two upper arms (一面二臂) with a crown on the head, armor on the body and a tokkosho, a pestle with a single sharp blade at each end--this being considered an attribute of Buddhist guardian figures as well as a symbolic item of Esoteric Buddhism--in his hand.

In Mikkyo (Esoteric Buddhism) there are some examples in which he has one face and two upper arms (一面二臂) with a crown on the head, armor on the body and a tokkosho, a pestle with a single sharp blade at each end--this being considered an attribute of Buddhist guardian figures as well as a symbolic item of Esoteric Buddhism--in his hand.

sen.j: また、白象にまたがった姿でも表現される。
sen.e: The other figure that he rides on an elephant is also seen.
The other figure depicts him riding an elephant.
The other figure depicts him riding a white elephant.

sen.j: 日本最古の遺存例は、法隆寺の玉虫厨子（飛鳥時代）に描かれた「施身聞偈図」（せしんもんげず）に見られるものである。
sen.e: The oldest work in Japan is seen in 'the picture of seshin monge, giving up the body to hear a verse of scripture' drawn on Tamamushi no zushi, the Beetle wing Shrine, (Asuka Period) in Horyu-ji Temple.

The oldest work in Japan is seen in 'the picture of Seshin Monge, giving up the body to hear a verse of scripture,' drawn on Tamamushi no zushi, the Beetle Wing Shrine, (Asuka period) at Horyu-ji Temple.

The oldest work in Japan is seen in 'the picture of Seshin Monge, giving up the body to hear a verse of scripture,' drawn on Tamamushi no zushi, the Beetle Wing Shrine, (Asuka period) at Horyu-ji Temple.

sen.j: 同寺の食堂（じきどう）には梵天・帝釈天の塑像（奈良時代）が安置されている（現在は大宝蔵院に安置）。
sen.e: At Jiki-do in Horyu-ji Temple was placed statues of Bonten and Taishakuten (Nara Period) (placed at Dai-Hozo-In (Great Treasure Gallery) at present).
At Jiki-do in Horyu-ji Temple were placed statues of Bonten and Taishakuten (Nara period) (currently placed at Dai-Hozo-In (Great Treasure Gallery).
At Jiki-do in Horyu-ji Temple were placed statues of Bonten and Taishakuten (Nara period) (currently placed at Dai-Hozo-In (Great Treasure Gallery).

sen.j: 東大寺法華堂（三月堂）には、乾漆造の梵天・帝釈天像（奈良時代）がある。
sen.e: At Hoke-do (Sangatsudo) in Todai-ji Temple, there are statues of Bonten and Taishakuten of kanshitsu-zukuri, Dry lacquer technique (Nara Period).
At Hoke-do (Sangatsudo) in Todai-ji Temple there are statues of Bonten and Taishakuten of kanshitsu-zukuri, done in the dry lacquer technique (Nara period).
At Hoke-do (Sangatsudo) in Todai-ji Temple there are statues of Bonten and Taishakuten of kanshitsu-zukuri, done in the dry lacquer technique (Nara period).

sen.j: 唐招提寺金堂には、梵天・帝釈天の木像（奈良時代）が見られる。
sen.e: At Toshodai-ji Temple Kondo there are wooden statues of Bonten and Taishakuten (Nara Period).
At Toshodai-ji Temple Kondo there are wooden statues of Bonten and Taishakuten (Nara period).
At Toshodai-ji Temple Kondo there are wooden statues of Bonten and Taishakuten (Nara period).

sen.j: 京都・東寺講堂には、密教系の白象に乗った木像（平安時代前期）が安置される。
sen.e: At the Toji Lecture Hall in Kyoto, a wooden statue on a white elephant, which is a characteristic of Mikkyo, is placed.
At the Toji Lecture Hall, in Kyoto, there is a wooden statue on a white elephant, which is characteristic of Mikkyo.
At the Toji Lecture Hall, in Kyoto, there is a wooden statue on a white elephant, which is characteristic of Mikkyo.（first stage of the Heian period)

sen.j: 日本においては庚申の日を縁日とする。
sen.e: In Japan Ennichi, hopping, is held on Koshin Day.
sen.cmt: 庚申の日→http://www.taishakuten.or.jp/index2.html、縁日→英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: In Japan, Ennichi (Hoping) is held on Koshin Day.
In Japan, Ennichi (Hoping) is held on Koshin Day.

sen.j: 帝釈天を安置する寺院としては、映画『男はつらいよ』で著名な東京都葛飾区の柴又帝釈天（題経寺）がある。
sen.e: For an example of the temple where Taishakuten is enshrined, Shibamata Taishakuten (Daikyo-ji Temple) at Katsushika Ward Tokyo is famous for the movie, Otoko Wa Tsurai Yo (It's Tough Being a Man).
sen.cmt: 男はつらいよ→http://www.japan-zone.com/modern/yamada_yoji.shtml、柴又帝釈天→http://www.taishakuten.or.jp/index2.html、題経寺→http://www.taishakuten.or.jp/index2.html
sen.e: For an example of the temple where Taishakuten is enshrined, Shibamata Taishakuten (Daikyo-ji Temple) in Tokyo's Katsushika Ward, has been made famous by the movie "Otoko Wa Tsurai Yo (It's Tough Being a Man)."

For an example of the temple where Taishakuten is enshrined, Shibamata Taishakuten (Daikyo-ji Temple) in Tokyo's Katsushika Ward, has been made famous by the movie "Otoko Wa Tsurai Yo (It's Tough Being a Man)."

sen.j: 18世紀後半に題経寺の本堂を修復している際に、紛失していた帝釈天の板本尊が発見され、その日が庚申だったことから、庚申の日を縁日とするという（詳しくは柴又帝釈天を参照）。
sen.e: Since the lost Ita-honzon (Wooden Main Deity) of Taishakuten was discovered during restoration of the main hall of Daikyo-ji Temple at the latter half of 18th centuries and it was on Koshin Day, so that Ennichi became to be held on Koshin Day (for detail, see Shibamata Taishakuten).

Since the lost Ita-honzon (wooden main deity) of Taishakuten was discovered during the restoration of the main hall of Daikyo-ji Temple one Koshin Day in the latter half of the eighteenth century, Ennichi became to be held on Koshin Day (for details, see "Shibamata Taishakuten").

Since the lost Ita-honzon (wooden main deity) of Taishakuten was discovered during the restoration of the main hall of Daikyo-ji Temple one Koshin Day in the latter half of the eighteenth century, Ennichi became to be held on Koshin Day (for details, see "Shibamata Taishakuten").

tit.j: 朝鮮の檀君神話と帝釈天
tit.e: Dankun myth in Korea and Taishakuten
tit.cmt: 朝鮮→英辞郎 on the WEB、檀君→Yahoo辞書
tit.e: The Dankun myth in Korea and Taishakuten
The Dankun myth in Korea and Taishakuten

sen.j: 朝鮮の高麗時代に成立した檀君神話においては、檀君朝鮮の始祖である檀君は、帝釈天（『三国遺事』では「桓因」）の庶子・桓雄と、雌熊が人間化した熊女との間に生まれた子ということになっている。
sen.e: In the Dankun myth which was established in Goryeo Period of Korea, Dankun, a founder of Dankun Korea, is regarded as a son who was born from Kanyu, a bastard child of Taishakuten (Kanin in 'Sangokuiji'), and a woman to whom a female bear humanized.
sen.cmt: 高麗時代→英辞郎 on the WEB、三国遺事→Yahoo辞書
sen.e: In the Dankun myth, which originated in the Goryeo period of Korea, Dankun, a founder of Dankun (Korea) is regarded as a son who was born from Kanyu, a bastard child of Taishakuten (Kanin in 'Sangokuiji'), and a woman that had humanized from a female bear.

In the Dankun myth, which originated in the Goryeo period of Korea, Dankun, a founder of Dankun (Korea) is regarded as a son who was born from Kanyu, a bastard child of Taishakuten (Kanin in 'Sangokuiji'), and a woman that had humanized from a female bear.
